meanings.definition: To establish a colony in (a place).
meanings.sent1: The explorers colonized the new land, building homes and farms.
meanings.sent2: Many European countries colonized various regions around the world in the past.
meanings.sent3: The ants colonized the picnic area, claiming all the crumbs for themselves.
meanings.sent4: The idea of freedom colonized her mind, pushing out all doubts and fears.
meanings.sent5: The vines quickly colonized the garden, covering every available surface with green leaves.

meanings.definition: To settle in (a place) as a colony.
meanings.sent1: Families from the city colonized the rural town, bringing new traditions with them.
meanings.sent2: The early settlers colonized the harsh land, adapting to its challenges.
meanings.sent3: The squirrels seemed to have colonized the backyard, storing nuts everywhere.
meanings.sent4: Laughter and joy colonized the room as friends gathered for a celebration.
meanings.sent5: The artist's creativity colonized the canvas, turning it into a masterpiece of colors and shapes.

meanings.definition: To subject (a place) to political control by another country.
meanings.sent1: The powerful empire colonized many smaller nations, imposing their laws and rulers.
meanings.sent2: History shows how some regions were colonized by foreign powers for resources.
meanings.sent3: The idea of a cat ruling the house seemed to have colonized the dog's dreams.
meanings.sent4: Fear and uncertainty colonized the minds of the citizens under oppressive rule.
meanings.sent5: The storm clouds colonized the sky, darkening the once bright day.
